Samuel and in this episode episode 36

you're watching this video right now and
you're hearing the words that I'm saying
that have been recorded and what we're
going to do is look at how that process
happens so let's get right into it we're
looking at a drawing of the air and
there are a few things that I want to
point out here okay here we can see that
this is the external part so this is the
external air and then we have this
section here and that is called I'm
going to draw a line down here that's
called the external auditory canal and
then here there's a structure that we
call the air drum connected to the air
drum we have three small bones we call
them the three bony articles the malleus
the incus and the stapes depending on
which book you read you'll see malleus
incus and stapes or hammer anvil and
stirrup they all mean the same thing
this is the hammer this is the anvil and
this is the stirrup I'm going to be
using malleus incus and stapes the way I
typically remember this is M I s Miss
malleus incus and stapes all right so
those are the three bones one here one
there and this is the third one here
then we have this structure here that

called the cochlea
and then we have let me do this in a
different color we have this structure
here and that is the auditory of course
because it deals with hearing the
auditory nerve and that of course goes
to the brain so these are the parts that
I want you to pay attention to once
again we have the external air and in
some places you're going to see this
called the Pina P I n na then we have
the external auditory canal we have the
air drum malleus incus and stapes the

a few other things that we have like
these are called the semicircular canals
I'm not going to talk about that much
today and then we have this connection
here where the stay piece connects to
the cochlea and that's called the oval
window and then there's the round window
and the other end of the cochlea so
these are the parts that I want you to
know and now we're going to talk about
how hearing happens and we're going to
kind of give an overview of the
mechanism of hearing now sound exists as
waves you have particles in the air that
are vibrating back and forth and this
kind of like an oscillation and that is
how the sound starts something vibrates
causing the air to vibrate and what
you're hearing is a result of this
process so the sound waves are coming
from some source let's say you're
listening to this right now which you
are we have sound waves that are coming
from the speaker's the speakers are
vibrating back and forth and the
external air focuses those sound waves
into the external auditory canal and the
air molecules are vibrating back and
forth and that vibration comes and
strikes the eardrum when the sound waves
strike the eardrum the eardrum is going
to vibrate back and
for the malleus incus and step is are
connected to the air drum the malleus is
connected to the air drum directly the
incus is connected to the malleus and
the stay piece is connected to the incas
so that causes those bones to vibrate
when those bones vibrate is going to
cause the oval window to vibrate and in
the cochlea which is what it's connected
to
we have fluid inside that cochlea when
the oval window vibrates the fluid
inside the cochlea is going to vibrate
and that's going to cause a series of
vibrations we're going to look at what's
going on in here in more detail in the
next episode
but the vibration in here is going to
cause a signal in the auditory nerve and
that signal then travels to the brain so
we have the same general mechanism when
it comes to senses there are receptors
inside of this cochlea that's going to
respond to the vibrating fluids that's
going to cause a receptor potential that
is going to cause a signal to be sent to
the brain and then the brain is going to
interpret that signal and in this case
it's going to interpret it as sound and
you're going to hear what I'm saying are
you going to hear something that you're
listening to whatever is the source of
that sound you will be able to hear it
because the brain is interpreting what
is happening with the receptors that are
found inside the cochlea there's one
more term I'd like to point out and that
is the air drum another name for the air
drum is also the tympanic membrane so if
you ever hear me referring to tympanic
membrane that is exactly the same thing
as the air drum I have an animation to

and there are a few things I want to

coming in here so the sound waves are
coming in here

those are vibrating causing stuff to
